awd_titl_txt: Recruiting and Fostering Students through Field Geoscience
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program supports the retention and graduation of high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need. Over a five-year period, this S-STEM project at the University of California at Davis will fund 50 undergraduate and 21 graduate scholarships for geoscience students in the fields of Geology and Coastal and Marine Sciences.  To recruit students into geosciences, the project will partner with eight area community colleges. Starting with this group, the project will systematically support students beginning with their first experience in field-based science. The project has a progression of follow-on experiences, including an undergraduate field course, research experiences, internships, and/or entry into graduate school. In addition to the undergraduate scholarships, the project will include "Jumpstart Scholarships" to first year graduate students. The broad range of opportunities for field-based experiences will serve opportunities to mentor students and enable student to get involved in increasing levels of research.  The expectation is that the financial, academic, and personal support for students will lead to increased recruitment, retention, and graduation in geoscience fields. 

This project will serve dual goals: education and research. The education goal is to recruit and retain highly qualified, low-income students in geosciences. The project aims to achieve this goal by supporting students from gateway geoscience courses to undergraduate majors, and into graduate school or geoscience professions.  The research goal is to test: (1) whether undergraduate field instruction can enhance content understanding and student engagement; and (2) whether the novelty of working in a field environment is an impediment to low-income and other underrepresented students, and how such novelty space can be reduced.  The second question addresses research suggesting that the novelty of being in an unfamiliar field environment can negatively impact student experiences and learning.  The project will assess whether this novelty-related anxiety may challenge low-income and other beginning geoscience students, and what interventions can mitigate novelty anxiety. This project has the potential to increase and broaden participation in geoscience, thus enhancing the future workforce of geoscience researchers, teachers, and industry professionals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview:  This project recruited low-income students at UC Davis to the geosciences, promoting them from gateway courses to undergraduate majors, and into graduate school or geoscience professions. In addition, the project assessed whether undergraduate field instruction and training can enhance student engagement and success.  Through Covid, we awarded scholarships, but the pandemic shut down field trips for much of the duration of this project.  Following the pandemic, we realigned the field component of the project, using unexpended funds to design capstone geological field trips, with a primary focus on intensive and multi-stage mentoring of students to prepare them for these experiences. 

Key Findings and Results: The UC Davis projected awarded a total of 93 scholarships to 59 unique individuals as well as providing 35 students with capstone geological experiences (to Hawaii and Iceland twice). S-STEM support was transformative to these students, as discussed under Broader Impacts below.  Our research focused on the impact of field instruction on training geoscience students for the workforce and/or graduate-level education.  Field experiences prior to the Covid pandemic consisted of mostly single-day trips for UC Davis and partner Community College earth science students.  While beneficial, these trips provided at best incremental benefits to participating students.  In contrast, the ambitious capstone trips designed after Covid were uniformly described as “transformative.”  These capstones were multifaceted and labor-intensive, , including extensive hands-on mentoring before each trip (preparation, funded and mentored gear purchases, a pre-trip multiday trip), during, and after each trip.  As one participant put it, “The capstone trip to Hawaii was an amazing field experience... I learned more on this trip than I ever have in any other educational setting, it just proves that the best learning happens in the field!”

Broader Impacts:  A total of 72 Academic Year scholarships were given to 51 unique undergraduate students; 39 summer field scholarships to 16 unique students; and 13 additional Jumpstart Awards to 13 students transitioning to grad school.  S-STEM scholarship awards recruited low-income students to the geosciences and allowed them to remain in the major through challenging and costly field requirements (e.g., required summer field classes required for licensure), and the program provided the support and guidance to allow these students to excel and move forward into graduate programs and the geoscience workforce.
